theText: Yes, out of curiosity. There is the prospect and risk of the introduction of
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Sinclair (New England) (11.28 A.m.)
theText: I just thank my colleague the honourableMC 2752 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 29 June 1995 apparent conflict. The line drawn between the absolute necessity, for public purposes, for there to be availability of information and the right of individuals to protect their own information as something sacrosanct is a fine line; and I accept that. But it worries me. It is not that anyone would suggest that,under every public service log or under every area of information, there is necessarily information to which everybody has a right to gain access. I want to talk in a minute about a few abuses of that which worry me. There is certainly a real problem: if you prevent information being disclosed, then it is going to be very difficult for the public servant in many instances to undertake his responsibility. It is also difficult for the public at large, if they are denied access to some of that information, to understand the processes of government; and, for ministers and for government itself, it becomes extraordinarily hard to formulate public policy. We have made a number of recommendations which are all trended towards the development of the privacy code to which the honourable member for Mitchell referred, and towards the prevention of undue disclosure. That is all an absolute necessity, but I am worried that there may be too much emphasis on the protection of the information as distinct from the real requirement to ensure that information is available for the purposes for which it is required. Of course, in stating the reasons that information is to be channelled between departments and the way in which there are to be controls, we have tried to ensure that there are not too many restraints; but it is a side of the privacy debate that needs to be identified. In the presentation of this report, it would be wrong if that were not given some emphasis. Having said that, and having agreed with my colleagues, I feel that there are two other important things to mention. Essentially, the days of the Internet have changed the availability of information and the access to it, in a way that really does promote enormous challenges. One of the examples where that is apparent is in a number of instances in recent revolutions, where it has been possible for information to be exchanged over the Internet about what is happening long before anyone else knows. In closed societies, such as those of China and the former Soviet Union, it has been particularly important, because the information has come out through the Internet before it has come out in any other form of communication, and that ensures that, in closed societies, there is some chance of knowing what goes on. The Internet has enormous implications in all sorts of ways, quite apart from those on which Kerry Packer is currently trying to capitalise. It is important that it be used in a way which does not unduly discourage individuals by making them feel that, whatever they say or do, everything they own and all their personal affairs are suddenly going to be available at large. Of course, that is the reason for our recommendation of a privacy code. One aspect of the availability of information that numbers of us have referred to over time has been the frequency with which, in recent times, individuals-particularly in Nigeria, but in Africa generally-have been writing to individuals to solicit funds or to suggest that there are huge sums of money available in some way for people to be given access to. A number of my own constituents have received such letters in the past fortnight. I have received one myself, in my private capacity. It appals me that out there, regrettably, there are likely to be people gullible enough to respond. I want to use the opportunity of this debate to say that, if anybody receives a letter of that sort-suggesting that there are many millions of available funds which, in some way, are going to be accessible to them and which they can pay into their bank account, perhaps gaining Thursday, 29 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2753 access to some commission for so doing-they should firstly take that letter to their nearest federal member. If they do not know who their federal member is, they should write to the federal Attorney-General, enclosing that letter. Under no circumstances should they try to make contact with the person whose name is on that letter . . There are several letters-there is not only one individual involved-and all of them are highly suspect. As I say, they are part of the invasion of privacy which the sale of confidential lists of names in fact represents. Unfortunately, the problem exists commercially as much as it does in the public sector, and these names may well have even come from the Stock Exchange, the Australian Securities Commission or electoral rolls. They could have come from anywhere. This isa very good example of behaviour which this particular report attempts to redress; I am concerned that the nature of the lure being offered is such that I have little doubt that people will be tempted to respond. I say to any of them that, if they have any doubts at all, and if they do not know the person writing the letter, they should not respond. They should take the letter to somebody else and get advice before they react to it in any way. I know of at least 20 instances in my own electorate in the last few weeks where such letters have been made available. They are all totally false. The funds to which the letters refer are non-existent, and the economies of the countries from which the letters emanate are in such a state that if they were true, it would be the people of those countries who would be prejudiced if any such transaction did result. Having said that, I commend the report; but I think there does need to be a balance between the public right to know and the essential privacy of the individual. In the report we have attempted to identify that balance. I believe it has been reasonably effectively secured, and for that reason I support the recommendations in the report. of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in supporting the 39 recommendations which the committee has handed down. This report on the protection of confidential personal and commercial information held by the Commonwealth is another indication of how effectively many of the committees of the House of Representatives are working. I had a previous term in this place from 1984 to 1987,and I have noticed a tremendous change in the ensuing years. There is a very real sense of cooperation in those committees. On many occasions we might not agree, but the result is that the reports which are handed down are thought provoking. As they are worked out, wherever possible we are able to come to common principles. The report we are discussing today has had a fairly long and tortuous history. It has been to two parliaments and it has been subjected to two Attorneys-General. Because of the recent trend to refer bills to the committee for consideration, perhaps it has not been possible to give this report the attention that this committee would otherwise have chosen to give to it. During the period over which this reference has been considered, four substantial reports on bills have been prepared in 10 months. I believe that both the government and the opposition have been very pleased with the way that the committee has been able to consider bills and bring forward recommendations, many of which have been considered and have been adopted by the parliament. That is the upside. The downside is that the report we are discussing today has been delayed. It was initially brought before the committee by the former Attorney-General, now a member of the committee, the honourable member for Holt( Mr Duffy). Terms of reference were
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Slipper (Fisher) (11.36 A.m.)
theText: I am pleased to join with other members of the HouseMC 2754 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 29 June 1995 advertised, and numbers of meetings and public hearings took place. Following the election in 1993 and the appointment of the current Attorney-General( Mr Lavarch) to that position, the terms of reference which have resulted in this report were seen as being of continuing significance, to the extent that the Attorney again referred the terms of reference to the committee on 28 May 1993. Further submissions were called for, and 109 submissions and 40 exhibits were received from a wide range of groups in society. This is one of the important aspects of the work of the committee system. We are able to advertise in newspapers, and people who have an interest in what the law should be or how the law should be changed are able to make a contribution. In this case we received contributions from civil liberties groups, consumer organisations, law societies, academics, financial institutions and, most importantly, Commonwealth departments and agencies. It is fairly clear that anyone who had an interest in this particular area of confidential information has brought forward a submission. We have brought forward a unanimous report, but, as the right honourable member for New England( Mr Sinclair) said a moment ago, as society in Australia becomes more complex we have a continuing conflict between the right of privacy of the individual and the right of the public to have access to information. Significantly, in the course of its deliberations the committee considered the possibility of the amalgamation of the Freedom of Information Act and the Privacy Act. There are views one way and the other. Initially I was sympathetic to bringing both of these acts under the same umbrella, but on reflection it was a decision of the committee that the two acts should continue to be separate acts. After all, they deal with different aspects of citizens' rights. The Freedom of Information Act concentrates on the right of the citizen to have access to information in the public arena, and the Privacy Act emphasises our individual rights to privacy. As has been indicated by prior speakers, what we need to do is to create a culture in the public services of Australia and in government agencies and, I believe, in the commercial organisations also, where the privacy of the individual is respected. It takes a while for such a culture to build up. It simply cannot be legislated for and it does not happen overnight. However, from the submissions we received and from the attitudes we were able to perceive from groups contacting us, I think that we are well along the way to an improvement in this culture of privacy. As society develops and becomes more complex and as technology gallops along, there are additional complications. The honourable member for Jagajaga( Mr Staples), in his contribution, drew our attention to a number of those matters. Most importantly, the committee has directed its attention to the need for computer security. As we have more people working at home-I do not know whether they would be called outworkers-on private computers, a lot of the information which would normally be stored in a central area goes home with the person. Clearly, what we need to do is to make sure that that information is subjected to the same rules, regulations and protections as information generally. Also, it is very important to realise that, as the government and all governments accept, the federal bureaucracy does not always have the best and most efficient means of handling matters and, as a result of this, we have more contracting out. The law must therefore be applied to the agencies contracting with government in order to make them responsible for privacy principles in the same way as the government bureaucracy itself. It would be terrible Thursday, ·29 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2755 if, in the purs.uit of financial efficiency and efficiency in government generally, we referred matters out to private organisations and, when those referrals were made, the citizen was no longer protected in the same way as a citizen would have been had matters continued to be handled by the government. It is very important that the committee has covered this in its recommendations. Another thing that we really have to look at is that, although there has been a growing appreciation in government of the need to preserve a citizen's privacy, because it has not been a high priority the junior pen-pusher-the junior office boy, or office person, to be politically correct-quite often has been responsible for privacy. The result is that there have been some fairly appalling lapses of privacy. The committee heard very disturbing examples where, in some cases,Commonwealth public servants have even sold information. That is very worrying. One of the recommendations very much necessary to treat privacy with the importance that we want it treated is to ensure that senior managers in government agencies and government bodies are indeed responsible for privacy. When one looks at the many and varied laws throughout Australia, one finds that different items of legislation provide for different levels of privacy in different circumstances. That is why I support very strongly the proposal of the committee that there be the development of a privacy code, so that we can have a consistency of standard. I certainly hope that the government takes this up when there are consultations between the Commonwealth government, on the one hand, and the various state and territory governments on the other. This really is very important. As the honourable member for Jagajaga pointed out, the government in this country needs to help create the legal, cultural and technological framework to make sure that we have the right approach to privacy in Australia. The right honourable member for New England also highlighted another matter which I was going to mention-the Internet. Almost on a daily basis, when we open the newspapers we find how this new technology is galloping along. I am told that there could be up to a billion people on the Internet by the year 2000 and currently in Australia we have 500,000 people who apparently are linked to the Internet. One really must look very seriously at the Internet to see how it is possible to protect the privacy of individuals because the. technology is different. It could be that our report may have been overtaken by technology and that a future committee must look at this again. It is one of those very important items of activity which must be consistently reviewed on a regular basis. The Internet and people surfing the Internet is very much a new phenomenon. One can imagine, if there is a breach of privacy, that it would be possible for that information to be put on the Internet and, by the year 2000, that information would be available to a billion people throughout the world. That is certainly a mind-boggling and very concerning situation. As prior speakers have indicated, this is a report which attracted the unanimous support of both coalition and government members. Some of us would have liked the report to have been a little more extensive in some areas, but it is vital for the government to recognise that this report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs is a unanimous report. It represents the collective wisdom of both sides of parliament. We sat down over a period of three years and sought to bring forward recommendations to the government. We have had many submissions and two sets of public hearings. We sat during two parliaments and the result is, in the dying stages of this parliament, we are fortunate to be able to present this report. . . MC2756 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 29 June 1995 I hope the minister looks at it very seriously because the current situation is, in my view, that the privacy of individuals in our society is inadequately protected by the current law. No reasonable person in Australia today will deny that privacy is inadequately protected, but,as the right honourable member for New England has pointed out and as I alluded to earlier; it is absolutely vital to ensure that there is a balance between the right of privacy of an individual on the one hand and the right of the public to have access to important information. I hope that the government will consider this report expeditiously. In the past some reports have taken far too long to be considered. In fact, the lead. time to a response to some of these reports has been so long that the report has been entirely out of date and committees have had to go back to the drawing board yet again. Because the committee has had quite a substantial amount of additional work during the period of its deliberations, already we have had to visit this area on two occasions and we have had two committees. I understand orily three members of the current committee were members of the previous committee and there has been a lot of duplication. It is important that the government takes on board what this committee has recommended, comes back promptly with a response and adopts as many of the recommendations contained in this report as is possible. I urge future Attorneys-General-we hope the next Attorney-General will be a member of the coalition-to continue to refer this subject matter on a regular basis to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. It is a vital area and we all have a vested interest in making sure that we have principles and laws of fairness and equity in this area on the statute books in Australia. I am very pleased to support the report and I join colleagues on both sides in doing so. I urge the government to give a prompt response and I hope that the response is a positive adoption and acceptance of the recommendations which we, as a committee, have made. House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I wish to bring to the attention of the House serious neglect of questions relating to the protection of confidentiality of information held by the Commonwealth. I refer in particular to the ASIS fiasco, as the entire history of the ASIS fiasco runs contrary to the spirit of the recommendations in this report. I particularly refer to the invasion of the privacy of ASIS officers and of the wife of one of the officers, and serious breaches of privacy and the principles of medical confidentiality. I will, in this context, examine the most publicised case, that of an officer whom I shall describe as 'officer 2'. The illegal and unethical treatment of officer 2 was the catalyst to the AS IS fiasco, as we are all aware. In 1989, friction developed between officer 2 and a Foreign Affairs colleagueMr Douglas Woodhouse, a senior Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade administrative officer-while en poste in New Delhi. False and malicious-indeed, defamatory-rumours concerning the officer and his wife were spread by Mr Woodhouse. Upon his return to Canberra, Mr Woodhouse made an unsigned and highly defamatory statement to AS IS management, on the condition that it would never be shown to the ASIS officer. denied natural justice and procedural fairness to the officer and his wife. Officer2 and his wife were placed in a Kafkaesque situation in which they were not informed of the nature of the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Aldred (Deakin) (11.49 A.m.)
theText: In this debate on the In confidence report of the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Cadman
theText: Oh!
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Aldred
theText: The member rightly expresses some concern. This extraordinary caveatThursday, 29 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2757 allegations against them, nor did they know the identities of the accusers. Thus they could not respond to the allegations. This action violated the safeguards rightly recommended in the report now before us. However, even this travesty of an inquiry, based on hearsay, triggered a second internal investigation in January 1991. The officer attempted to resolve these rumours by approaching the present director-general, Mr Rex Stevenson, without resolution. The second inquiry, which concluded on 28 May 1991, was again based on hearsay and unsigned statements, and was critical of the officer. Once again, all key witnesses refused to sign their combined records of conversation without serious qualifications. Understandably, the officer found its verdict bizarre, and formally lodged a grievance through internal ASIS procedures. On 30 April 1991, the officer began a series of complaints to the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, Mr Roger Holdich. Consistent with the record of that farcical organisation, nothing was· resolved. The most significant document in the ASIS fiasco is the secret report of the AS IS grievance panel of 12 July 1991. The ASIS grievance· panel was headed by one of the most widely respected and outstanding officers in ASIS, a staff and welfare association representative and an independent member-a former senior diplomat. Its findings were unanimous. The grievance panel found, inter alia, that officer 2 had 'a satisfactory work record and some of his operational work was assessed as above average'. It also found that 'internal AS IS inquiries' had been 'unreasonably protracted and biased against the officer'. The grievance panel found that the ASIS investigation had placed an 'unreasonable strain on the officer's family' and 'that the matter should have been settled much sooner'. Further, it stated that the portrayal of the officer by ASIS inquiries was 'overstated and biased'. The grievance panel also found that the officer's assessments for 1989 and 1990, relevant to the grievance panel's inquiries, were 'missing', that 'it would appear they have been hidden or destroyed', and that they were believed by the panel to be favourable to the officer. In plain English, AS IS internal investigators had deliberately destroyed the officer's relevant records, which would have supported his case. This is a most appalling indictment. The deliberate destruction of Commonwealth documents isa serious offence, and violates the principles and procedures espoused in the In confidence report. . The ASIS panel recommended that the officer's operational record be corrected and that the officer was suitable for further work. Indeed, it pointed out that the Director-General of ASIS valued the work of the officer and wanted to keep the officer on staff. Most pointedly, the grievance panel found that, if the officer proceeded to leave ASIS, 'His separation provisions should be handled in a cooperative and generous way.' Due to Senator Evans's negligence, they were not. The most significant unexamined matter in the AS IS fiasco which is of special relevance to the In confidence report is the malevolent role of Mr Douglas Woodhouse, the senior DFAT officer who was the source of the allegations against officer 2 and his wife, which allegations the Samuels report accurately described as 'little more than unauthenticated gossip'. Mr Woodhouse consistently refused to sign these allegations, even when officially requested by ASIS. Mr Woodhouse also claimed that the officer's wife was 'a security risk'-although she was not on the ASIS staff-and threatened her that 'he would destroy her husband'. In a most serious breach of the Privacy Act and confidentiality, Mr Woodhouse claimed to use as a 'subsource' the doctor of the officer's wife who, according to Mr Woodhouse, MC 2758 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 29 June 1995 reported that the wife of the officer was receiving psychiatric treatment and was suicidal. Significantly, a recent DFAT possible parliamentary question brief prepared in May 1995 for Senator Evans suggested that ASIS could legally receive from, and use, medical information from a doctor of an Australian citizen without revealing the source. The PPQ reveals DFAT's and the Attorney-General's Department's contempt for the Privacy Act and principles of medical confidentiality. This conduct highlights a major deficiency in the In confidence report we are now debating in that it merely confines its concerns about medical confidentiality to cancer and epidemiology. However, the issues of the political use of medical information and invasion of privacy are much broader. Senator Evans should be condemned for the use of KGB psychological tactics. I refer to Senator Evans's use of a rumour based pseudo-psychological report prepared by ASIS and used uncritically by Mr Roger Holdich and Mr Rex Stevenson for the so-called confidential briefing of Senator Sue Knowles and other senior Liberal MPs. I emphasise that the use of the so-called psychological report was on Senator Evans's initiative. Senator Evans's actions were explicitly criticised in Justice Samuels's report as 'highly inappropriate'. So much for DFAT and Senator Evans's respect for medical ethics and the Privacy Act. After the ASIS fiasco, Senator Evans can never again be described as a champion of civil liberties or human rights. He would certainly be highly uncomfortable with the general approach of the In confidence report. No investigation of the ASIS fiasco would be complete without the most rigorous scrutiny of the role of Mr Woodhouse and the motives for his grossly improper and illegal conduct. I refer to Mr Woodhouse's allegations which were made on his imposed condition that they were not to be disclosed to the officer or his wife. It should be pointed out that Mr Woodhouse has had no formal training for investigations of any kind. Characteristically, DFAT, in its indomitable style, rewarded Mr Woodhouse by promoting him to be head of the fraud and discipline unit. He is now enjoying his unearned fruits of a valued position in Washington. Yet Senator Evans, at a Senate estimates committee on 31 August 1993, at a time when Woodhouse's role in the AS IS fiasco was well known to him, described him as 'an outstanding officer from my experience'. Evidently, Senator Evans approves of Woodhouse's KGB management style based on character assassination. The question must be asked: why has Mr Woodhouse escaped punishment for his serious criminal offences against DFAT and AS IS officers? The dust over the AS IS fiasco has not settled. The In confidence report by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs will, by bringing debate on privacy concerns to the fore, make it more difficult to cover up the AS IS fiasco. Threatening to imprison journalists and muzzle the press are no solutions to the security fiasco that Senator Evans has created. The government has nothing to gain by tapping the telephones of journalists, including that of Sydney Morning Herald journalist David Lague or the ASIS officers concerned in the recent controversy. This is a most lamentable invasion of the privacy of individuals in a democracy. The use of medical records, especially contrived or deliberately misinterpreted, as in the ASIS fiasco, and used as a form of character assassination, as in the ASIS case, should have no place in Australia. Thursday, 29 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2759 I call on the Attorney-General( Mr Lavarch) to stop the telephone interceptions of our most noted journalists and related surveillance. We must defend press freedom, even though Senator Evans suddenly finds press freedom a personally repugnant concept. Nor should DSD ever again engage in, or distribute, the product of interception of international telephone calls made by Australian citizens, as it did in the ASIS fiasco,· especially when these citizens were the major complainants to an inquiry to which the government was a party. It is widely recognised that there is an ineluctable tension between the principles of privacy and publicity in a democratic society .. However, this government is incapable of achieving the fine balance necessary to ease that tension. In failing to respond to the challenge in a mature manner, it is at odds with the philosophical approach taken in the In confidence report. I recommend careful study of the In confidence report to the government. They are obviously in need of guidance from this report, which, hopefully, it will provide. I seek leave to table the possible parliamentary question which is referred to in this speech. I commend the In confidence report to the House. Leave granted. Debate (on motion by Mr Fitzgibbon) adjourned. Industry, Science and Technology Committee Report Debated resumed from 26 June, on motion by Mrs Easson: That the House take note of the paper. . . . and the winner is? CouldI .indicate at the outset my appreciation of the work of the member for Lowe( Mrs Easson) and the member for Bendigo( Mr Reid), both of whom carried the brunt of this inquiry, together with the secretarial staff. It is worth noting, when you compare to it some other committee reports, the relative promptness with which this report was written. The inquiry obviously concerned the year 2000 Olympics and the contribution the games can make to Australia's image in the region. More particularly, the inquiry looked at the sports equipment industry, issues such as the marketing of Olympic merchandise, the question of the infrastructure that will develop around the Olympics and, in general, Australia's possible gains from this Olympic win. CouldI at the outset also raise in a bigger sense the question of employment and its relationship with this inquiry. The main reason I am particularly interested in that aspect is the fact that a predominant part of the Olympics site is in my electorate. It is worth noting that the central west region of Sydney, in the last quarter figures, has an unemployment rate of 10.7 per cent, two percentage points above the national average. It is also worth keeping in mind that there was a very strong drop in the unemployment rate in the region in the last year, going down by 4Y2 per cent, whereas the national trend only went down by 1.6 per cent. To some degree it is catching up but it is still at a higher level. It is also worth noting that in the particular municipality where the Olympics are sited, Auburn, the unemployment level is significantly higher than in the other two councils areas that constitute that sub-region. There is a particular problem in regard to unemployment in this region. I took opportunity to write to some companies, trying to register with them the need to employ local labour to partly overcome this problem. There have been some embryonic
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Ferguson (Reid) (Midday)
theText: I wish to speak on the report entitled Olympics 2000Me 2760 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 29 June 1995 efforts made by the Auburn Council but it tends to be a council· with minimal staffing and really it has not focused enough on the problem. I have to say also that there have been some gestures by the Department of Employment, Education and Training to try to ensure that its local agencies provide a good part of the work force. It is worth noting in a broader sense Discussion Paper No.3, Creating jobs, by Peter McDonald, where he said on page 30 when referring to this region and the north-west region of Melbourne: Both are old industrial areas which did not fare well in the shake-out that occurred in manufacturing industry in the early 1980s. Both have a large pool of unemployed persons in manufacturing, construction and transport. Taken together, these two areas alone contain almost 130,000 unemployed persons, about one i.n six of Australia's total of unemployed people and an even bigger proportion of those who are unlikely to benefit from current and future economic growth. . He further stated on page 32: There is potential for redevelopment for the Ford site in Homebush ... That is very close to the Olympics site. He continued: The mid-west of Sydney has two additional features which cannot be ignored. The first is the principal site of the Year 2000 Olympic Games is within the region. The second is that the region contains locations which can function as regional centres providing for the possibility of commercial expansion. This applies especially to Parramatta. We have here the reality that there is very high unemployment. We have the presence of the Olympics but we have the possibility of actually doing something about it. In an article in the Australian Quarterly, Winter 1995, in regard to the region and the related question of unemployment in the region, Phillip O'Neill and Robert Fagan said: Jobs in the service sector provided most employment growth in the western suburbs between 1986 and 1991 but often remained inaccessible to retrenched manufacturing workers, especially from NESB groups, and young people although they were often located in the same or adjacent LGAs. Local geography exerts a major influence over people's access to waged work. Commuting costs have a major impact on the incomes of low-wage workers concentrated in lower-cost housing areas on the metropolitan fringes. Public transport is inadequate in western Sydney especially for cross-hauling between suburbs. Continued suburbanisation of economic activity has made this increasingly common in the 1990s. This discriminates severely against young people and women in one-car families. Using public transport can also become a security fear for people having to cope with the changing working hours, especially for part-time positions in manufacturing and retailing establishments. Information sources about employment opportunities both regionally and in the wider labour market are often relatively poor amongst the people most vulnerable to high unemployment rates. Finally, there is considerable anecdotal evidence, at least, of discrimination by prospective employees in the willer Sydney labour market against employing 'westies' given their long journeys to work and social stereotyping. As I have said, this Olympic site is in a region that has significant problems. More particularly, the unemployment problem in that region is related to the high proportion of people from a non-English speaking background. An article by Ian Burnley and James Forrestcoincidentally, in the same journal-about unemployment levels states: For males, there is a focus on the western (Parramatta, Blacktown, Penrith), southwestern (Bankstown, Liverpool, Campbelltown) and southern suburbs (Sutherland) ... But there is a greater focus among females in the middle western suburbs: from Parramatta extending to Auburn and Ryde and northwestwards into Hornsby. These are not high unemployment areas for the general population, and emphasise therefore the particular impacts of birth place/gender disadvantage derived from occupational segregation. Thursday, 29 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2761 As I said, I was absent, and not able to playa big role in the committee's inquiry but I can see the need to focus on the applicability of a lot of these suggestions to local hire and to working with companies and the CES to ensure that this stereotyping and discrimination against people in that region is overcome. Turning to the broader inquiry, I think it substantially deals with the major problems. It is worth noting what the report it has to say about the Olympics and what it will be providing. On page 5 of the summary it notes that, for the first time in Olympic history, all athletes will be housed in the Olympic Village at Homebush Bay, that the majority of venues will be within 30 minutes of the Olympic Village, that competition in 14 sports will be held at Homebush Bay, that 15,000 media people are expected to converge on Sydney, and that every night of the games 220,000 additional people are expected to be staying in Sydney. That gives us some dimensions of the issues and the possible ramifications. One of the important focuses of the Olympic planning of the previous state government, and it is being followed through by the new state government, is the concern with the environment. This inquiry notes the very good work done in respect of energy conservation and the use of renewable sources, water conservation, waste avoidance and minimisation, protecting human health, and protecting natural and cultural environments in the area. There has been significant remediation of what was once a very contaminated site due to a variety of uses for such things as abattoirs, timber yards, and fairly unsavoury industrial plants, et cetera. There has been very significant regeneration of Homebush Bay and, to a large degree, that was the reason that this site was chosen. It is worth noting the comments of Karla Bell from Greenpeace. I think we are aware that Greenpeace played a very substantial role in making sure that Sydney's bid was environmentally strong and therefore more viable for support. She stated: It is no good just doing a bit of energy conservation because they have been doing that in Europe for 20 years . . . You have to leapfrog technologies, and you have to move into renewable technologies. It is no good doing tertiary treatment on sewage just because we do only primary at Malabar ... What you have to do is waste water recycling et cetera. She is focusing there on the possibilities in the environmental fieldsand that relates again to Australian manufacturing industries. If we can get a bit of visibility, and a bit of success through this village, and through some of the companies that are connected with it, it is certainly good for what is an expanding international industry. In the consideration of the use of solar energy and energy efficient appliances, recycling surplus heating from air conditioning, the use of recyclable packaging and non-toxic materials, and the question of public transport and all those things, these games have provided a very strong focus for trying to maximise the advantages and minimise the unattractive outcomes from the environmental point of view. The inquiry report said: 2.84 In this context, selling the success of the remediation project is critical. Controversy over the environmental credentials of the Sydney Olympics has the potential to damage public confidence in the Games and to adversely affect Australia's reputation on environment issues. Given our rather poor performance at the Berlin conference on updates on global warming, anything we can do to improve our image is worthwhile. Specifically on the solar question, as people are aware, Australia did a lot of work on this aspect, and on page 33 the inquiry notes: MC 2762 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 29 June 1995 2.91 The proponents of solar technology for the Olympic Games site foresee an impediment which the Commonwealth can help to overcome in relation to planning. To make the site a viable and environmentally sound urban development it is claimed that an energy audit is .needed before other detailed planning is undertaken . . . 2.92 According to Dr Mills, an energy audit of the site is needed now to allow energy planning to proceed. To provide a platform for an innovative 'environmental urban development', proper planning should require the addressing of energy requirements up front. The inquiry is essentially saying that we have an industry in which Australia is at the head of the field-or has been traditionally, at least-and that this energy audit is a very serious requirement in relation to the general work that is being done on the environment of the site. Public transport has been briefly mentioned, and one of the issues that is on the agenda with the New South Wales state government is the question of whether there will be an in-out railway line or loop. This is a very important ingredient of the environmental issues of the games. Certainly, a loop in and out of the site would provide a lot quicker system, thus ensuring that the number of people using cars will be minimised. For the difference in the amount of money there is between the up-front costs of a simple one-track loop and the long term costs, there can be no argument whatsoever but that we should go for that system which maximises public transport use and minimises car use within the games. The other suggestions of the inquiry cover a variety of issues that are really out there in the marketplace and are central to the games and their place in Australian industry. The committee has suggested that there be additional funding for an Olympics tourism marketing campaign. I do not think we need to elaborate upon the vital nature of tourism to Australia's gross domestic product. It is such that, this week in parliament, it is leading policy debate in large part in areas such as visa policy and the export market development grant changes. Once again, this committee is saying that tourism is a central requirement of the country and that there should be additional funding for it. With regard to broadcasting, we are quite aware that these Olympics will provide the most up-to-date technologies. Some of those that have been mentioned as having a lot wider applicability for the future are optical fibre, compressed digital video, multimedia, interactive media, digital television, and high-definition TV. The inquiry report says that there should be a strategy for the introduction of new broadcasting technologies to Australia in time for those Olympics. Both sides of politics are certainly aware of that massive requirement for this country. We are also concerned-and this is, once again, a widely held view in Australia industry, and this particular committee has previously dealt with it-about the question of purchasing policy. The inquiry report says that there should be the collection and provision of information on the level of Australian industry involvement. Perhaps the committee could have been a bit more radical and could have pushed on the question of pressurising industry to actually do it. But at least it is a step in the right direction that we are saying that that information should be out there and available for public and industry knowledge. We have sought that an electronic commerce system for the Olympic Games be developed, and that there be an Olympic employment skills study. This study would involve actually finding out what skills are required so that, if any shortage is going to come on line, we do not deal with it in the normal, conventional fashion of this country by trying to bring in 5,000 Italian stonemasons or some such, but we actually get out there in the training sector and try, in advance, to do something about it. Thursday, 29 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2763 Once again, this is an opportunity to promote Australian sporting expertise. As the economies of our region improve and the middle class grows in these countries, there is more demand and more concern for fitness and more access to sporting time, leisure, et cetera. These games provide Australia with an opportunity to market itself in those crucial fields and, of course, in the very closely related area of sporting equipment. The report essentially says that Australian industry should seek to maximise its opportunities, and it certainly covers the issue of the environmental standards that have been a major hallmark of this submission and the resulting successful application. I commend the report to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Fitzgibbon) adjourned.
